sending-an-email_key3: Once you are logged in to your email provider’s SMTP server, you can call the sendmail() method to actually send the email. The sendmail() method call looks like this:
sending-an-email_key4:
{}
The sendmail() method requires three arguments.
sending-an-email_key5: Your email address as a `string` (for the email’s “from” address)
sending-an-email_key6: The recipient’s email address as a `string` or a list of `strings` for multiple recipients (for the “to” address)
sending-an-email_key8: The start of the email body `string` must begin with 'Subject: \n' for the subject line of the email. The '\n' newline character separates the subject line from the main body of the email.
sending-an-email_key9: The return value from sendmail() is a dictionary. There will be one `key`-value pair in the dictionary for each recipient for whom email delivery failed. An empty dictionary means all recipients were successfully sent the email.
sending-an-email_key11: Be sure to call the quit() method when you are done sending emails. This will disconnect your program from the SMTP server.
sending-an-email_key12:
(221, b'2.0.0 closing connection ko10sm23097611pbd.52 - gsmtp')
The 221 in the return value means the session is ending.
sending-an-email_key13: To review all the steps for connecting and logging in to the server, sending email, and disconnection, see Sending Email.
